required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Why in Hospital After VATS Lobectomy
clinical_study.official_title: Why Are Patients Still in Hospital After Video-Assisted Thoracoscopic Surgery Lobectomy?

brief_summary.textblock:
The study aims to identify specific or potential reasons that prolong the length of hospital stay after video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery lobectomy.
The hypothesis is that patients who are still in hospital after video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery lobectomy are associated with prolonged air leak, infection, pneumonia, atrial fibrillation or other complications or social factors.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Through study completion, an average of 2 days

secondary_outcome.measure: Number and frequency of postoperative complications
Numeric rating scale for postoperative pain in hospitalization
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Through study completion, an average of 2 days
secondary_outcome.description: Patients are scored using a numeric rating scale ranging from 0 (no pain) to 10 (excruciating pain) per day.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Duration from postoperative chest tube placement to potential removal, an average of 2 days
secondary_outcome.description: The criteria of drain removal is that air leak was consistently below 20 ml/min for at least 12 hours and fluid production was non-bloody and non-chylous without an upper volume limit.

arm_group.description: All consecutive patients scheduled for video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery lobectomy.

intervention.description: Patients have a longer length of hospital stay than the common recommendation.

study_pop.textblock: Patients underwent VATS lobectomy and writing informed consent.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients referred to elective VATS lobectomy
- Speaks and understands Danish
- Informed consent obtained
Exclusion Criteria:
•Age < 18 years
